p:
There are few studies that investigate the effects of omega-3 fatty acids on collagen biology. It is know that peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR-γ) regulates numerous biological processes, among them, collagen synthesis
45 . An in vitro study, using mouse embryonic fibroblasts (MEF) demonstrated that loss of PPAR-γ is associated with up regulation of collagen synthesis, at least in part, due to the TGF-β pathway
45 . Omega-3 fatty acids, such as EPA, are natural ligands of PPAR-γ
46– 48 . So, one possibility for the results observed in the present study is that EPA activated PPAR-γ which then disturbed collagen organization. This hypothesis is in agreement with the observations that, in vitro treatment of keloids fibroblasts with DHA (0–100 μM) reduced α-smooth muscle actin, type III collagen and TGF-β1 receptor expressions. Once again, these effects seem to be related to PPAR-γ signaling
49 .
